key_points: A deadly shooting on a New Mexico film set involving Alec Baldwin has highlighted the importance of firearms safety during film production.
Paul Biddiss, a former British Army paratrooper turned film military advisor, emphasizes the paramount importance of weapons safety on set.
Halyna Hutchins was killed and Joel Souza injured when Alec Baldwin discharged a prop gun on the set of the western film “Rust”.
The Santa Fe County Sheriff’s Department stated that the investigation remains open and active, with no charges filed yet.
Incidents involving firearms are rare in the film industry thanks to extensive safety protocols.
Biddiss explains that prop weapons can be actual firearms modified to fire blanks, which still pose risks.
Detail on the use of restrictors and blank-firing adapters to make automatic weapons safe for filming.
The article references the death of actor Brandon Lee on the set of “The Crow” as a previous firearms incident in the film industry.
Weapons safety on film sets involves extensive training, weapons inspections, and adherence to strict protocols.
The film’s armorer, responsible for weapon safety, was among the witnesses interviewed by police.
spokespersons: Paul Biddiss (former British Army paratrooper, film military advisor)
